title: Clair Bee
text:
Clair Francis Bee (March 2, 1896 – May 20, 1983) was an American <a href="basketball">basketball</a> coach, who led the team at <a href="LIU%20Brooklyn">Long Island University</a> in <a href="Brooklyn%2C%20New%20York">Brooklyn, New York</a> to undefeated seasons in 1936 and 1939, as well as two <a href="National%20Invitation%20Tournament">National Invitation Tournament</a> titles in 1939 and 1941. 
Biography.
Bee was born in <a href="Grafton%2C%20West%20Virginia">Grafton, West Virginia</a> to James Edward Bee (1871–1933) and Margaret Ann Skinner. Later, Bee was a graduate of <a href="Waynesburg%20University">Waynesburg University</a> (then Waynesburg College) where he played football, baseball, and tennis.
Bee's teams won 95 percent of their games from 1931 to 1951, including 43 in a row from 1935 to 1937. Bee holds the Division I NCAA record for highest winning percentage, winning 83% of the games he was head coach. Bee resigned in 1951 after several of his players were implicated in the <a href="CCNY%20Point%20Shaving%20Scandal">CCNY Point Shaving Scandal</a>. LIU shut down its athletic program shortly afterward.
Bee also coached the <a href="American%20football">football</a> team at LIU until it was disbanded in 1940.
He coached the <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">National Basketball Association</a>'s <a href="Baltimore%20Bullets%20%281944%E2%80%931954%29">Baltimore Bullets</a> from 1952 to 1954, amassing a 34–116 record under his tenure.
Bee was known as the "Innovator". His contributions to the game of basketball include the 1–3–1 <a href="zone%20defense">zone defense</a> and the <a href="three-second%20rule">three-second rule</a>. Bee also served as co-host of the early NBC sports-oriented television program "Campus Hoopla" on WNBT from 1946 to 1947.
His influence on the game also extended to strategies sports camps (Camp All-America), (Kutsher's Sports Academy), writing technical coaching books, and conducting coaching clinics around the world. By the time he left coaching in the 1950s, Bee had already begun writing the <a href="Chip%20Hilton">Chip Hilton</a> Sports Series for younger readers.
Bee was inducted into the <a href="Basketball%20Hall%20Of%20Fame">Basketball Hall Of Fame</a> in 1968. The <a href="Clair%20Bee%20Coach%20of%20the%20Year%20Award">Clair Bee Coach of the Year Award</a> is awarded every year to a coach who makes an outstanding contribution to the game of <a href="college">college</a> basketball, and the <a href="Chip%20Hilton%20Player%20of%20the%20Year%20Award">Chip Hilton Player of the Year Award</a> is awarded to a men's basketball player.
In 1968, he cofounded the <a href="Kutsher%27s%20Sports%20Academy">Kutsher's Sports Academy</a>.
One of Bee's grandfathers was <a href="Ephraim%20Bee">Ephraim Bee</a>, a member of the first <a href="West%20Virginia%20Legislature">West Virginia Legislature</a>.
